qas.question: Firewalls and exit procedures are considered what?
What is defined as a way of filtering network data between a host or network and another network?
What does a physical firewall consist of?

answers.text: a separate machine filtering network traffic

qas.question: What type of machines normall have a firewall?
Computer security is mostly comprised of what?
Which system has a built in firewall?
What is another form of having a firewall connected?
Which part of a Linux computer is the firewall built into?
What types of measures do computer security firms rarely use today?

plausible_answers.text: machines that are permanently connected to the Internet

qas.question: What type of machine rarely uses firewalls?

plausible_answers.text: a way of filtering network data between a host or a network and another network

qas.question: What type of OS does not use the operating system kernel?

context: Today, <a4_0>computer security<a4_0/> comprises mainly <a0_0><b5_0>"<b10_0>preventive<b10_0/>" measures<b5_0/><a0_0/>, like firewalls or an exit procedure. <a1_0>A firewall<a1_0/> can be defined as <b12_0>a way of filtering network data between a host or a network and another network<b12_0/>, such as the Internet, and can be implemented as <b6_0><b13_0>software running on the machine<b13_0/><b6_0/>, <b8_0>hooking into the network stack<b8_0/> (or, in the case of most UNIX-based operating systems such as <b7_0><b14_0>Linux<b14_0/><b7_0/>, built into the <b9_0>operating system kernel<b9_0/>) to provide real time filtering and blocking. Another implementation is a so-called physical firewall which consists of <a2_0>a separate machine filtering network traffic<a2_0/>. Firewalls are common amongst <b11_0>machines that are <a3_0>permanently connected to the Internet<b11_0/><a3_0/>.
